726618f-c.title: Queens: Queens Boulevard - Union Turnpike
726618f-c.text:
Flushing Meadow Park (Queens): The car yards of New York City's Independent System Subway at the south end of the park, viewing eastward from Queens Boulevard and Union Turnpike. Note
road construction for the World's Fair 1939-40.

View 1 April 23, 1936
View 2: June 29, 1936
View 3: July 7, 1940

P. L. Sperr

728116f-c.title: Queens: Union Turnpike - Queens Boulevard
728116f-c.text:
Union Turnpike, north side, between Queens Boulevard and Vleigh Place (Head of Vleigh Road.), showing in a set of four views the Willow Glen Stock Farm of Timothy Jackson from 1873 to 1891.

1922.
Views 1,2 & 3.
View 4: January 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

728117f-a.title: Queens: Union Turnpike - Queens Boulevard
728117f-a.text:
(1 & 2)

Union Turnpike, northside, between Queens Boulevard and Vleigh Place (formerly The Head of The Vleigh Road; now non existent). This is a set of two views, showing the old Willow Glen Horse farm.

January 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)

The same, another view. This was the Furman Homestead occupied during the Revolution by William Furman Sr.

About 1927?

Arthur White.

728123f-b.title: Queens: Union Turnpike - Queens Boulevard
728123f-b.text:
Union Turnpike, between Queens Boulevard and Vleigh Place (Head of the Vleigh Road, showing the farm house of Timothy J. Jackson. This farm, comprised of 77 acres, was used as a stock farm. On it was a one-half mile circular trotting course. This Jackson, maintained a general store just west of L. Younger's house which was on the N.W. corner of Vleigh Place and Union Turnpike. No buildings appear on any of the Queens Atlases after 1909 and the only buildings that appear on that year are near the northern boundary of the property, just south of Edgar H. Meeker's property. Cord Meyer became the owner of this property after 1891. For a number of years he operated a pumping station. This is a set of four views taken on different days and from different angles. It is probable that if these buildings were standing in 1937 they would be between 132nd and 138th Street. However they were demolished sometime in 1929.

October 1928.
Views 1, 2 & 3.
View 4: April 1929.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
728123f-b.folder: Union Turnpike & Queens Boulevard, Queens, NY

728115f-a.title: Queens: Union Turnpike - Queens Boulevard
728115f-a.text:
Union Turnpike, north side, between Queens Boulevard and Vleigh Place (head of the Vleigh Road.), showing the water works of Cord Meyer (sunken buildings) which stand on the former farm of Timothy T. Jackson. These buildings are at about 135th Street.

April 1929.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
